name__text: Deakin University School of Exercise and Nutrition VCE PE Program
description__text:
VCE Physical Education: Turning theory into practice
Deakin University?s School of Exercise and Nutrition Sciences offers VCE Physical Education classes the opportunity to gain an insight into exercise science testing and evaluation in a laboratory or clinical environment at our Melbourne Burwood Campus.
The program offers you, as a physical education teacher, a great opportunity to reinforce aspects of the VCE curriculum, using Deakin University?s first class performance laboratories. Students will interact with sport scientists whilst conducting and interpreting a range of laboratory tests. Schools may choose one or both of the laboratory sessions as well as take a tour of other facilities within the University.

Lab 1: Physiological assessment of exercise
Linked to VCE Physical Education Unit 1: The Human Body in Motion, and Unit 3: Movement Skills and Energy for Physical Activity.Area of Study: How does the body produce energy?
In this lab, students will explore common laboratory methods to assess aerobic and anaerobic fitness. Aerobic capacity will be assessed using a progressive exercise test to exhaustion (VO2max test). Assessment of the lactate inflection point will also be discussed, which can be applied to sporting and pacing strategies. The anaerobic energy systems will be assessed using a 10s and 30s power test on a bicycle ergometer. Discussion of how these tests relate to fitness and energy system utilisation during exercise will then be discussed.

Lab 2: Kinematics of movement: Resistance training
Linked to VCE Physical Education Unit 4: Training to Improve Performance.Area of Study: How is training implemented effectively to improve performance.
In this lab, students will instruct, perform, and analyse several foundational resistance training exercises such as the squat, deadlift and the bench press. Kinematics of movement,ÿincluding force, velocity and power output will be explored using GymAware software. Students will evaluate vertical jump performance of class members using portable force plates, and training variables used to enhance vertical jump height in gym-based settings will be explored. The principles of chronic muscle adaptation in response to resistance training will be discussed as part of this session, with a focus on integrating resistance training into athletes programs to enhance sporting performance.

Session information:
Dates: Monday 17 ? Friday 21 June, 2019 Monday 24 ? Friday 28 June, 2019
3 time slots available per laboratory per day: 8:00am - 10:00am; 10:30am - 12:30pm; 1:00pm - 3:00pm (times are flexible and can be adjusted if needed)Session duration: 2 hours
Cost per session: $150 +GSTNote: Maximum of 25 students per session

For more information please contact sens_enquire@deakin.edu.au or 9244 5052. 
We look forward to seeing you there!
School of Exercise and Nutrition SciencesDeakin University
summary: VCE Physical Education: Turning theory into practice Deakin University's School of Exercise and Nutrition Sciences offers VCE Physical Educa

name__text: Deakin University School of Exercise and Nutrition VCE Food Studies Program
description__text:
VCE Food and Nutrition: Turning theory into practice
Deakin University?s School of Exercise and Nutrition Sciences offers VCE Food Studies students the opportunity to gain an insight into topical areas of food and nutrition in a laboratory environment at our Melbourne Burwood Campus.
The program offers you, as a Food Studies teacher, a great opportunity to reinforce aspects of the VCE curriculum, using Deakin University?s first class food laboratories. Students will interact with food and nutrition scientists whilst conducting and interpreting a range of laboratory tests. Schools may choose one or both of the laboratory sessions as well as take a tour of other facilities within the University.

Lab 1: Food Makers
Linked to VCE Food Studies Unit 2: Food Makers.Area of Study 2: Food in the Home
In this experience, students will explore the three basic methods of sensory evaluation. Discrimination testing will be conducted to determine whether a difference exists between food samples. Descriptive testing will be conducted to determine the nature and intensity of attributes in food samples. Preference testing will be conducted to determine how well food samples are liked. How these tests relate to the science of judging and evaluating the quality of food by the use of the senses (taste, smell, sight, touch and hearing) will then be discussed.Our VCE School Visit Program provides Food Studies students with valuable, practical laboratory experiences that will illustrate and demonstrate the applications of important food industry principles.

Lab 2: Healthy and sustainable food from paddock to plate
Linked to VCE Food Studies Unit 4: Food issues, challenges and futures.Areas of Study: Unit 4: Area of study 1 ? environment and ethics & Area of study 2 ? navigating food information
In this hands-on activity, students will track a fresh food item from paddock to plate, incorporating a variety of activities addressing sustainability, food security, food waste, labelling and health. Students will use specialised lab equipment, similar to that used in industry, to determine an item?s quality, then prepare and evaluate a food product using the items that would be labelled as ?second grade?. They will then explore packaging techniques that could be applied to their developed food product and finally, they will use specialised software to determine the products? specific nutrient content and use this along with online tools to explore writing a health claim.

Session information:
Dates: Monday 17 ? Friday 21 June, 2019 Monday 24 ? Friday 28 June, 2019
3 time slots available per laboratory per day: 8:00am - 10:00am; 10:30am - 12:30pm; 1:00pm - 3:00pm (times are flexible and can be adjusted if needed)Session duration: 2 hours
Cost per session: $150 +GSTNote: Maximum of 25 students per session

For more information please contact sens_enquire@deakin.edu.au or 9244 5052. 
We look forward to seeing you there!
School of Exercise and Nutrition SciencesDeakin University

description__text:
POSITIVE PATHWAYS, BETTER FUTURES
Community Transition Support (CTS) 2019 Conference will be held at the Moonee Valley Race Club, Wednesday 5 June 2019.



The CTS 2019 conference will explore how specialist schools and their communities can work together to improve post-school career outcomes for young people with intellectual disabilities.



The day will be themed around innovation, advocacy and forming positive expectations of what young people with disabilities can achieve.
Master of Ceremonies: Dr Shanti Wongÿ
Keynote Address: Dr Joanne Webber ? Disability Inclusion
Dr Joanne Webber has worked in disability-inclusive education in Australia and across the Asia Pacific region for the past 20 years.ÿThe rights and empowerment of people with a disability has been at the forefront of Joanne?s work with a focus on meaningful inclusion and the capacity development.
Hear from speakers;
Bernadette Gigliotti ? CEO CEAV Institute, Zita Pinta - Seven Ways Consultancy, Peter Kellock ? INLLEN,ÿ Stefanie Dimov - Melbourne University,ÿKris Parsons - Jackson School,ÿBrooke Briody - Principal of Melton Specialist School andÿMartin Collins ? DET Youth Pathways and Transitions Manager
Presentations and workshops will cover;

Results of the 2018/19 Data Collection & Research projects
Career development - preparing school leavers for the employment landscape of tomorrowInclusion & Advocacy - Community action for meaningful pathways.
Examine the Youth Employment Study (YES) project by the University of Melbourne
Explore examples of good practice within local schools and communities
Network with a range of local community services and government providers that support young people




Workshop Announced:ÿ

Community Connections:ÿConor Hickey & Steve Costello - Collingwood Children?s Farmÿ
Map Your Future:ÿMiia Tolvanen & Luke David - Youth Disability Advocacy Service (YDAS)ÿVictoria?s only youth-specific disability advocacy service
Engagement Co-Design Framework (ECDF):ÿEmma McCarthy
Building Ability through Career Management:ÿJoanne Webber & CEAV




The conference program will include a panel discussion

Dr Joanne Webber ? Disability Inclusion
Brooke Briody - Principal of Melton Specialist School
Martin Collins ? DET Youth Pathways and Transitions Manager
Kris Parsons ? Leading Teacher, Jackson School

?How do we increase the future employment opportunities for both open employment and unpaid (voluntary) work of young people with disabilities? What areas of support can we improve on to ensure young people obtain and sustain long-term meaningful work??



Networking opportunities
Community organisation and NDS?s disability employment services stalls
Uniting, OCTEC, Campbell Page, YDAS, Onemda, We support U, interact, WCIG, atwork Australia, NSS, Gforce, Brite Services



Who should attend?
The 2019 Conference is aimed at schools.ÿ Ideally, a school should send a team of people who support young people to make successful post-school transitions.ÿ

School Leaders
Pathways and Transition coordinators
VET/VCAL coordinators
Wellbeing coordinators

Other organisations are welcome to attend, especially those interested in entering into a partnership with a specialist school.

Further education providers
Community organisations
Local government
Employers




For more information email Bret atÿbmahon@inllen.org.au
Please advise of any dietary requirements.
summary: POSITIVE PATHWAYS, BETTER FUTURES Community Transition Support (CTS) 2019 Conference will be held at the Moonee Valley Race Club, Wednesday

name__text: 2019 Performance and Development Workshops for Education Support Staff (Workshop 1)
description__text:

Half day workshops and two hour webinars will provide Education Support (ES) staff with strategies and skills to effectively implement the performance and development approach and to prepare individualised performance and development plans (PDP) to support their professional development and are aligned to overall school goals.

Develop strategies to achieve their goals, and identify relevant sources of evidence to demonstrate and track their achievement 
Create effective improvement strategies to support performance and professional growth.

Please note, once your have registered for the workshop, you will be sent an email with venue details and instructions for the pre workshop activity.ÿ

name__text: 2019 Performance and Development Workshops for Learning Specialists (Workshop 1)
description__text:
Workshops have been specifically designed for learning specialists (and teams of learning specialists) in Victorian government school settings. Only appointed learning specialists will be eligible to participate in this workshop.
What is being offered
Half-day workshopsÿwill provide learning specialists with an opportunity to define their role, share strategies and reflect on aspects of their practice to increase the impact of their role within the school setting. 
ÿ
These workshops will support learning specialists to:

increase role clarity in the context of their school
identify personal goals and professional learning that will increase their capability
collect evidence to support and demonstrate their professional achievements.

Workshop content will be aligned with the Professional Standards, High Impact Teaching Strategies (HITS) and the Framework for Improving Student Outcomes (FISO). 
Please note, once your have registered for the workshop, you will be sent an email with venue details and instructions for the pre workshop activity.ÿ
summary: Workshops have been specifically designed for learning specialists (and teams of learning specialists) in Victorian government school settin

description__text:
After the success of last year's Iftar we are going ahead with our second event. Given the opportunity to build bridges between cultures we invite people of all faiths to join this event.ÿStudents undertaking Ramadan are especially asked to invite their friends and families to join them in learning about their culture and sharing in a meal.ÿ

As two of our school values includeÿCuriosityÿandÿCommunity, what better way to display them than by coming along and meeting families, discovering something new about a different culture or just your own?ÿ
FAQs
Who can I bring to the Iftar?
Members of your immediate family are invited. Children need to be supervised whilst at Coburg High School, but please bring the kids! This is an informal event and families are encouraged to move about, meet others and enjoy themselves.ÿÿ
What food can I bring to the Iftar?
If Ramadan is part of your culture, please bring the traditional foods and drinks that you usually eat and drink. We may have a range of cultures represented: Saudi, Lebanese, Somalian, Pakistani, etc. If an Iftar is new to you, then you may wish to bring any usual dinner foods that can be shared with others. A more creative option is to attempt some Iftar classics. This may mean doing a little Googling or better yet having a conversation or two on Sydney road! Either way, sticking to Halal foods will mean that all can share.
What drinks can I bring to the Iftar?ÿ
There are certain drinks that usually only make an appearance during Iftar, otherwise, fruit juices are the go. Apart from being 'Haram' (forbidden) alcohol is not allowed.ÿÿ
How much food should I bring to the Iftar?
Be reasonable. You do not need enough to feed everyone and if everyone brings enough for a family, there will be plenty! If you have a unique drink, something sweet, or an amazing talent in the kitchen - your food might go quicker.
How will we share food?ÿ
Table areas will be set up for people to share. Floor space will also be an option. Students may wish to organise with their friends beforehand who will share with who.ÿÿ
Do I have to fast before the Iftar?ÿ
No! If you are not observing Ramadan then you do not need to fast during the day, but to make the experience more geniune you may wish to. In many Isamic countries, food options are limited during daylight hours of Ramadan, so many Westerners have gone through the experience by default!ÿ
Will there be microwaves for reheating food?ÿ
Yes, there will be access to microwaves.
Will there be access to sinks for cleaning?ÿ
Yes, there will be access several sinks?
Should I bring disposable cups, plates etc. ?ÿ
As we have access to sinks, plastic plates or other washable plates would be good. Disposable items are convenient but create waste, please try to minimise the use of disposable items.ÿ
Will there be a place for people to pray?ÿ
Yes, there will be some designated spaces upstairs in the main building for males and females.ÿÿ
summary: After the success of last year's Iftar we are going ahead with our second event. Given the opportunity to build bridges between cultures we

description__text: The Ainger Peck Public Speaking Award is an effective speaking contest that is open to secondary school students from interested schools in the Metropolitan Area. This competition is open to secondary school students in years 7 to 12. Students can choose their own topic to speak on and have a time limit of 4 minutes.\r\nThis competition is about effective speaking where the ability of the speaker to ?communicate? with the audience is being judged. The award promotes and enhances communication skills and helps develop the art of public speaking. It aims to hone skills in confident verbal communication and will give students who take part an invaluable experience.\r\nMaximum of 3 students per school can be registered.
summary: The Ainger Peck Public Speaking Award is an effective speaking contest that is open to secondary school students from interested schools in

name__text: U.S. Colleges Visiting Melbourne - Liberal Arts and Sciences in the United States: Different sizes and approaches - Learn from them!
description__text:
To learn first-hand from U.S college admissions speicliasts who visit the region.ÿ There inforamtion is priceless as they share with you how to access opportunities of attending a college/univeristy in the United States.ÿ 
This session will connect students and their families with representatives from these accredited U.S. Colleges that will focus on opportunities through Liberal Arts and Sciences in the United States that will represent instituitons of different sizes and different approaches.ÿThis session will address tips when applying to highly selective colleges and universities in the U.S.ÿ Come and learn from them! ÿ
The information that will be delivered will become invaluable as it can help you explore possibilities and pursue your goals of appplying to your best-fit college. They will address the following:


Characteristics of Liberal Arts Colleges


Benefits and outcomes of a liberal arts education


The application reading and committee process


Tips on the selective U.S. college admission process and finding the right ?fit?


Specific information on each institution


We are thrilled that Carey Baptist Grammar School is hosting this event in Melbourne for all interested students, families and school staff.ÿParticipating U.S. Universities that are making the trip to Melbourne on Wednesday 8th May include:
1.ÿClaremont McKenna College (California)
2.ÿAmherst Collegeÿ(Massachusetts)
3. Davidson Collegeÿ(North Carolina)
4.ÿUniversity of Notre Dame (Indiana)ÿ
Venue Information
Where: Carey Baptist Grammar SchoolDate: Wednesday May 8thRoom: Building C - Room C201Time:ÿ 5:30pm - 7:30pmMap:ÿhttps://www.carey.com.au/about/kew-campus
EducationUSA Country Coordinator Samantha Jackson will also be in attendance on the night andÿIf you have questions prior to the event contact Samantha at MelbourneEdUSA@state.gov or include with your registration.
Registration:ÿNumbers will be limited and once the venue reaches capacity registration will be closed. Register via the link:ÿhttp://bit.ly/2J5MUzj
We look forward to you attending and using this as a great opportunity of learning and using the information gained on the night in helping you prepare your U.S. college applications!ÿ
Learn more about these colleges:ÿ
Liberal Arts and Sciences Colleges are a distinctive option for students who are seeking a more individualized and personal higher education experience. Liberal Arts Colleges support the development of the whole student by focusing solely on the undergraduate student. Students have the opportunity to be intensely involved in deep and meaningful learning experiences such as high-level research, concentrated internships, and engaging living communities. Students develop life-long critical thinking skills, communication strategies, and progressive leadership skills. Liberal Arts Colleges are unique to the U.S. higher education landscape and have proud and notable alumni as leaders in business, education, government, medicine, law, and many other fields.ÿ
Claremont McKenna College (CMC) - #9 US News and World Report, Best Liberal Arts and Sciences College (2019). Located in Southern California. CMC was founded at the end of World War II to educate veterans returning from the war for lives of leadership in Business, Government, and the Professions. Known as an institution that preaches ?learning for the sake of doing?, CMC focuses on the practical application of the Liberal Arts, placing an emphasis on research and internships as an integral part of the undergraduate experience.
Amherst College - #2 US News and World Report, Best Liberal Arts and Sciences College (2019). Located in the Northeast of the US in the state of Massachusetts. Amherst is perennially ranked as one of the best Liberal Arts and Sciences colleges in the country due to its diverse educational offering and academic standards. Founded in 1821, students are prepared to use ideas to make a difference in the world with an emphasis on developing critical thinking using small classes, an open curriculum, and a diverse student body. Amherst is one of 5 colleges and universities in the US that offers full-financial aid in a ?need-blind? process for international students.
Davidson College - #10 US News and World Report, Best Liberal Arts and Sciences College (2019). Located outside of Charlotte, North Carolina. A traditional liberal arts and sciences college that offers 26 majors and seeks intellectually curious students committed to service and leadership. Davidson is one of the smallest NCAA Division 1 schools which allows it to offer top athletics, along with one of the best liberal arts curricula in the country. A unique aspect of Davidson is its Honour Code, which places trust in its students and allows them a unique set of freedoms within the academy.
University of Notre Dame - #17 US News and World Report, Best National Universities (2019). Located in South Bend, Indiana. One of America?s leading national research universities. Founded to be a great Catholic university in 1842, Notre Dame is faithful to both its religious and intellectual traditions. With 5 different colleges (Architecture, Arts and Letters, Business, Engineering, and Global Affairs) the academics at Notre Dame are comprehensive and wide ranging. It has a commitment to undergraduate teaching as well as research.
summary: To learn first-hand from U.S college admissions speicliasts who visit the region.  There inforamtion is priceless as they share with you how
